page.title:
Do D0 Detectors Observe Radiation Aging?
Do D0 Detectors Observe Radiation Aging?
page.enlisting:
• After 3 years of data taking and ~10% of expected Run II luminosity • D0 has experienced painful muon drift chambers aging issues during Run I ◆ ~50% of chambers not used for physics analysis ◆ Closest to the interaction region chambers have electrodes replaced (~20%) ◆ Other chambers have higher flow rate and gas filtering in re-circulation system ⬧ Run II shielding reduced particle fluxes by factor of ~10 per unit of delivered ◆ Fast heating of the wires method is developed to “clean” the wires • Lessons (D0 plus other detectors) ◆ Radiation aging is very dangerous – you can damage your detector badly ◆ There are un-expected issues with detectors aging which are very difficult ◆ We have to constantly monitor for signs of “aging” and act well in advance ⬧ Use of un-tested organic materials during construction ⬧ Aging effects seen with charges as low as ~1mC/cm ⬧ Neutron doses vs gamma doses, etc. • After 3 years of data taking and ~10% of expected Run II luminosity • D0 has experienced painful muon drift chambers aging issues during Run I ◆ ~50% of chambers not used for physics analysis ◆ Closest to the interaction region chambers have electrodes replaced (~20%) ◆ Other chambers have higher flow rate and gas filtering in re-circulation system ⬧ Run II shielding reduced particle fluxes by factor of ~10 per unit of delivered ◆ Fast heating of the wires method is developed to “clean” the wires • Lessons (D0 plus other detectors) ◆ Radiation aging is very dangerous – you can damage your detector badly ◆ There are un-expected issues with detectors aging which are very difficult ◆ We have to constantly monitor for signs of “aging” and act well in advance • After 3 years of data taking and ~10% of expected Run II luminosity
• After 3 years of data taking and ~10% of expected Run II luminosity • A f t e r
